discourse_list.title: MIP-6: Porter Finance Fixed Rate DAO Bonds Onboarding Application

content.content: Who is the interested party for this collateral application? Porter Finance, a bond issuance platform for DAOs. Provide a brief high-level overview of the project, with a focus on the applying collateral token. Porter Finance allows DAOs to issue and sell zero-coupon bonds to raise capital. DAOs over-collateralize bonds with assets from their treasuries and provide an on-chain promise to repay. Porter Finance underwrites bond issuances by thoroughly reviewing the issuing DAO’s financials and analyzing the risk of the collateral provided. Porter addresses a gap in on-chain capital markets. Up until this point, DAOs in need of capital, even those that generate significant revenue, have had no option but to sell tokens either in private or public markets. This can mis-align incentives and be dilutive to token holders. Porter recognizes that the DAO landscape is far too diverse to be adequately serviced by a single capital markets strategy (token sales). Just like companies, DAOs have working capital needs: marketing, research & development, paying and acquiring contributors, and payment of service providers, among other things. Companies that generate revenue have the luxury of accessing a diverse array of financing: revenue backed finance, factoring, supply chain finance, lines of credit, venture debt, bonds, debentures etc. Porter seeks to open the aperture of on-chain capital markets by offering revenue-producing DAOs the opportunity to access what are, effectively, corporate bond markets, and to maintain protocol-owned liquidity. Unlike corporate bonds, however, the terms (security interest, convertibility, covenants etc.) embedded in DAO bonds are mediated by smart contracts rather than legal ones. An extension of this fact is the replacement of legal risk with smart contract risk. This adds a new layer of determinism and composability to debt capital markets. We’ve undergone a Zellic audit and are currently undergoing another through Spearbit which will be completed before the late May launch. The DAO bonds themselves, as well as the issuing DAO’s treasury assets, implement the ERC-20 standard. So far, and for the purposes of this application, Porter has implemented two zero-coupon bond structures: a simple and a convert. Simple refers to a bond, secured by assets, that is either refinanced or paid down at maturity. Convert refers to convertibility, or the option retained by the bond buyer to exercise a conversion of the bond ERC-20 to the issuer’s native tokens. Provide a brief history of the project. Porter Finance is planning on launching in late May. The protocol has been under development since January 1st, 2022. It has raised funding from respected funds such as Dragonfly Capital, ParaFi Capital, and Nascent Ventures as well as notable DeFi veterans such as Robert Leshner and Kain Warwick. Porter Finance is advised by Sidney Powell, the CEO and co-founder of Maple Finance. Sidney has over half a decade of experience in corporate finance and credit risk. In Q1 2022, Maple surpassed $1BN in loans originated with no defaults. It is the most successful DeFi protocol that underwrites credit risk. ShapeShift is an official launch partner of Porter Finance. They will be issuing debt through our platform to refinance an existing debt position that is being used to pay their contributors. ShapeShift is profitable and has generated over $14M of revenue in 2022 alone. Their monthly revenues have consistently increased since inception in October 2021. We look forward to helping grow their thriving business by capitalizing them with DAI. Ribbon is another launch partner we are working with. They will be raising a few million dollars via our platform for a few potential uses: scaling the team, protocol owned liquidity, bootstrapping fuse pool liquidity, and relending unused capital. Implementation In the proposed implementation, MakerDAO may deploy the D3M to finance DAO bonds through Porter Finance at a fixed cost of capital. MakerDAO would selectively fund specific DAO bond issuances on the Porter platform. Currently, bonds are sold via an auction where market participants make bid orders with a volume and price. If the order is competitive, the order gets filled at auction clearance.  Slide 16_9 - 31148×682 32 KB  There can only be one currency used for the bond issuance and auction. MakerDAO can use this to their advantage by guaranteeing the issuing DAO a bid with a competitive price and volume in exchange for them issuing their bond in DAI. This will create organic demand equivalent to the whole issuance size, while MakerDAO only has to commit the amount of DAI in their bid. In addition to the interest generated by the DAO bonds, MakerDAO would also benefit from 5% emissions of Porter’s native token. The collateral against which DAI is minted will be the ERC20 token that represents the bond issued. Link the whitepaper, documentation portals, and source code for the system(s) that interact with the proposed collateral, and all relevant Ethereum addresses. If the system is complex, schematic(s) are especially appreciated. Documentation Source code Link any available audits of the project. Both procedural and smart contract focused audits.    GitHub    GitHub - porter-finance/audits: 🔒 Reports from our protocol audits. 🔒 Reports from our protocol audits. Contribute to porter-finance/audits development by creating an account on GitHub.      Link to any active communities relating to your project.    Discord    Join the Porter Discord Server! The Porter community is building a decentralized credit market so that DAOs can grow and thrive. | 2,222 members      How is the applying collateral type currently used? Bonds are sold to fixed income investors looking to generate yield by lending to creditworthy DAOs. Does one organization bear legal responsibility for the collateral? What jurisdiction does that organization reside in? Porter Finance is incorporated in the US and claims no legal responsibility for the bonds issued through its smart contracts. DAOs issuing bonds are typically unincorporated and thus do not reside in any jurisdiction. Where does exchange for the asset occur? The asset exchange occurs via a Gnosis Auction. Issuing DAOs mint bonds via Porter Finance smart contracts and sell them via Gnosis Auction smart contracts.

Interesting. If built correctly, this presents an opportunity to enhance working capital markets with the determinism of smart contracts. As I understand it, some of the credit risk endemic to an off-chain corporate bond would be mitigated by the programmatic guarantee of a security interest in an issuer’s native tokens. Is this in fact the case? How does Porter underwrite the issuing DAOs creditworthiness and the defensibility of the collateral pledged? Does it use historical revenues/profits and back into a debt service coverage ratio? As you may have read, a key motivator for MakerDAO is to generate organic demand for DAI. In your experience, do DAOs who might borrow via DAI bonds want to pay operating expenses in DAI? Is there an argument to be made that this sort of lending would support to a stickier form of DAI? The potential for liquidity and composability of this debt primitive is significant. If Maker can get comfortable with the credit (big if) of the participating DAOs, it’d be strategically sensible to help build out the bond bridge. One can already envision this as the kernel for securitization markets to sprout…Maker ingests a diversity of DAO bonds, pools them, and sells off exposures to other credit investors as per their appetites. Once a decent volume of DAO bonds is floating around, we could further imagine the genesis of a derivatives market that points at such index assets (Credit Default Swaps, synthetic indices, etc.)

Jordan:  MakerDAO would selectively fund specific DAO bond issuances on the Porter platform. Currently, bonds are sold via an auction  where market participants make bid orders with a volume and price. If the order is competitive, the order gets filled at auction clearance.   I personally believe one of the next frontiers in DeFi is Fixed Income and platforms like FiatDAO, DebtDAO, and Porter have the first step. With that in mind, is this MIP6 requesting a D3M implementation for both the Simple & Convert Bonds? And is it reasonable to think of a Simple Bond as a Junior Tranche? Also, can you please provide more color on liquidation risk, such as incurring bad debt, or unbacked debt, during the liquidation process–like if Bonds cannot be sold at a sufficiently large average price in order for Porter to recover the debt outstanding.
@flipflopflapdelegate I imagine a bright future where every senior financial claim of any good (whitelisted) DeFi protocol will be financed by $DAI. The Age of the D3M!

As I understand it, some of the credit risk endemic to an off-chain corporate bond would be mitigated by the programmatic guarantee of a security interest in an issuer’s native tokens. Is this in fact the case?  Exactly! Borrowing DAOs lock tokenized collateral in their bond contracts as a prerequisite to issuing bonds. This removes the need for a third party to escrow the collateral by creating a programmatically guaranteed security interest.  How does Porter underwrite the issuing DAOs creditworthiness and the defensibility of the collateral pledged? Does it use historical revenues/profits and back into a debt service coverage ratio?  Porter underwrites bond issuances through the performance of a credit analysis. We review six key factors to predict the probability of a DAO defaulting on debt: character, capital, capacity, conditions, collateral, and contracts. Historical revenues/profits are covered in the “capacity” portion of the analysis. We have an overview of our underwriting process laid out here in our documentation.  In your experience, do DAOs who might borrow via DAI bonds want to pay operating expenses in DAI? Is there an argument to be made that this sort of lending would support to a stickier form of DAI?  Yes, this is what gets me so excited about this partnership! From our conversations with DAOs, we’ve learned that DAI is sometimes preferred over more centralized stable coins such as USDC. Some DAOs are concerned about the non-zero risk of Circle banning them from using USDC and therefore are more comfortable using DAI. Therefore, DAI borrowed by these DAOs would be much stickier as it is much  more likely to be held in the treasury and used to pay contributors.

With that in mind, is this MIP6 requesting a D3M implementation for both the Simple & Convert Bonds?  Yes, we are requesting both simple and convertible bonds to be used. They both share a similar low-risk profile due to DAOs going through verification, underwriting, heavily over-collateralizing issuances, and signing an on-chain promise of repayment.  And is it reasonable to think of a Simple Bond as a Junior Tranche?  Both convertible and simple bonds do not support tranching in their current form, however this is something we will be implementing in future products. Although, due to their composability coming from the implementation of the ERC-20 interface, bonds can be pooled and tranched in aggregate by anyone ingesting them. As @teej mentioned in his response, MakerDAO could ingest multiple bonds, pool them, and sell off a junior tranche to mitigate its risk.  Also, can you please provide more color on liquidation risk, such as incurring bad debt, or unbacked debt, during the liquidation process–like if Bonds cannot be sold at a sufficiently large average price in order for Porter to recover the debt outstanding.  As a platform, we are heavily incentivized to mitigate the risk our lenders are taking. DAOs heavily over-collateralize their issuances, go through verification and underwriting, and sign on-chain promises of repayment to mitigate the risk a lender takes. However, if a default does occur, MakerDAO, as a bondholder, would be able to exchange their bonds for the collateral provided. Due to the heavy over-collateralization required, it is likely that this collateral would be more than enough to cover the principal plus interest owed. In the unlikely event where this is not the case, MakerDAO would incur bad debt and take a loss on this loan. Diversification through allocation to multiple bonds is something MakerDAO can do to mitigate this risk.

@Jordan Congratulations on your application. Can you please provide your thoughts on the below points: What is the typical tenor of these bonds? Would it make sense to go with equity issuance (tokens) at an early stage as failure to repay the bonds (debt) can lead to catastrophic results for the DAO/bond issuer? Do DAOs view this as supplementary capital in addition to equity already raised (similar to venture debt)?

Porter combines: (1) The collateral framework of over-collateralized lending (Crypto-lending, Maker’s core) with (2) The deployment framework of wholesale B2B lending (D3M) That liquid ERC-20s would serve as MakerDAO’s security interest is mechanically no different than existing wBTC, ETH, or LINK vaults. BUT quite differently, Maker would take exposure, albeit at low leverage (maybe 20-40% LTV), to long-tail assets (DAO tokens) it would otherwise (probably) not permit as eligible collateral at home. These DAO assets presumably wouldn’t be eligible collateral for native Maker vaults because the cost-benefit analysis falls short. i.e. the ((Annual Borrow Volume)*(Interest Rate)) doesn’t offset the (vault implementation cost amortized + annual oracle costs). A framing for token holders to consider: Why might we be comfortable taking long-tail collateral risk “abroad” that we would not be comfortable taking “at home”? What are the innate benefits to a Porter integration that might offset such risks? Fodder: Wholesale lending relinquishes control for gains in scale. (1) Underwriting (risk pricing, structuring leverage profile, etc.) and (2) oracle costs are exported. So we ought to be comfortable that both are being managed correctly. A follow-up for @Jordan: Collateral Framework (1) I have spent some time with Porter’s underwriting docs, as I think the issue of how Porter underwrites is of primary importance here. Would you be willing to do an underwriting case study on the forums? In other words, how do you practically evaluate an issuer and its native token along the dimensions of character, capital, capacity, conditions, collateral, and contracts? (2) Part of Maker’s reluctance to onboard long-tail collateral is oracle costs relative to revenue. How does Porter manage marks/oracles? Is it oracle-less? Do you use Chainlink DONs? Deployment Framework How do you envision a D3M practically being implemented? The D3M acts as a cost ceiling for borrowers. It is designed to bring predictability to borrowers on platforms that MakerDAO is confident can execute well. So do you propose that MakerDAO guarantee fixed terms (interest rate, duration, LTV) for ALL DAO issuers on the platform? Or that MakerDAO and Porter agree that D3M liquidity can be accessed only for DAOs who meet certain thresholds? i.e. equal to or above a “6” on a credit rating scale of 1-10.

Thanks @Vishal_Mehta!  What is the typical tenor of these bonds?  We are seeing demand for tenors between 6 and 24 months. Only the most creditworthy DAOs who possess strong market positioning, solid teams, and robust revenues will be approved for longer tenors due to the increased risk.  Would it make sense to go with equity issuance (tokens) at an early stage as failure to repay the bonds (debt) can lead to catastrophic results for the DAO/bond issuer?  We aren’t against the idea of equity issuance. This is the current standard for how DAOs raise capital currently. However, debt issuance can be a sustainable, low cost alternative for DAOs.  Do DAOs view this as supplementary capital in addition to equity already raised (similar to venture debt)?  Yes. We see debt issuance as one tool in the financial toolbelt of DAOs. Equity issuance and debt issuance can be used harmoniously to create a lower weighted average cost of capital for DAOs.

Why might we be comfortable taking long-tail collateral risk “abroad” that we would not be comfortable taking “at home”? What are the innate benefits to a Porter integration that might offset such risks?  MakerDAO would be taking much less risk working with Porter Finance than using long-tail collateral directly. DAOs issuing bonds through Porter Finance heavily over-collateralize their borrowing as well as sign an on-chain document promising to repay. This allows borrowing DAO augment tokenized collateral provided with their social credit, something MakerDAO does not currently leverage.  (1) Would you be willing to do an underwriting case study on the forums? In other words, how do you practically evaluate an issuer and its native token along the dimensions of character, capital, capacity, conditions, collateral, and contracts?  Of course! We are currently underwriting our launch group issuances and will post one of them as a case study to increase transparency for the Maker community.  (2) Part of Maker’s reluctance to onboard long-tail collateral is oracle costs relative to revenue. How does Porter manage marks/oracles? Is it oracle-less? Do you use Chainlink DONs?  Porter’s infrastructure is oracle-less.  How do you envision a D3M practically being implemented? The D3M acts as a cost ceiling for borrowers. It is designed to bring predictability to borrowers on platforms that MakerDAO is confident can execute well. So do you propose that MakerDAO guarantee fixed terms (interest rate, duration, LTV) for ALL DAO issuers on the platform? Or that MakerDAO and Porter agree that D3M liquidity can be accessed only for DAOs who meet certain thresholds? i.e. equal to or above a “6” on a credit rating scale of 1-10.  Because bond terms are bespoke to each issuing DAO, it may make sense to take a more flexible approach. Porter is currently underwriting issuances with the intent of accurately pricing risk. I believe it would be most efficient and practical for MakerDAO to commit to offering liquidity to DAOs who meet certain credit requirements. Porter can create an outline of these thresholds and work with MakerDAO to determine which can access D3M liquidity.

Thanks for the application Jordan. What’s the TAM for this market in your view and could you talk a bit about Porter’s strategy to scale and what level of exposure Porter plans to take on in the short and medium term? DAO financing seems like a natural fit for Maker to get in on the ground floor of and support, especially to the extent that incentives are aligned and the DAO decides to help bootstrap Porter. As you pointed out, DAI in DAO treasuries is much stickier than DAI used in DeFi. Could you please also share some information about the liquidation process should the collateralization ratio fall below the specified level?

At this point the following questions: How long has Porter Finance existed? What is the performance record (in terms of losses) over the lifetime this has operated? How does Porter Make money? What is the exposure to rate changes (example say short term rates rise another 1-2% in next 12 months). What sort of Stability Fee are you envisioning for this facility, and initial debt ceiling? How is this ‘oracleless’.? Where does the underlying trade, and more importantly who can trade it?

Interesting application Should we think of these DAO loans together as a CLO with portfolio constraints? Is the underlying token collateral marked to market and the debt liquidated if it falls below certain triggers?

What’s the TAM for this market in your view and could you talk a bit about Porter’s strategy to scale?  It’s tough to get exact numbers on this, but we estimate there are around $5B of assets in DAO treasuries. Because we expect issuances to have LTV’s around 20%, we can assume the TAM to be $1B at the current market size. We plan to grow alongside the DAOs we are directing capital towards. As they invest in their businesses, they will grow, allowing us to scale up their credit facilities.  What level of exposure Porter plans to take on in the short and medium term?  Can you expand on this?  Could you please also share some information about the liquidation process should the collateralization ratio fall below the specified level?  We do not liquidate DAOs. Instead, we establish creditworthiness through a credit analysis and rate the issuance. As proposed above, it may make sense for MakerDAO to only offer liquidity to DAOs achieving certain ratings. We also require issuances to be heavily overcollateralized and the issuing DAOs must sign an on-chain promise to repay.

Great questions!  How long has Porter Finance existed?  We incorporated in September of last year.  What is the performance record (in terms of losses) over the lifetime this has operated?  We have not launched yet. We are planning on launching later this month.  How does Porter Make money?  Porter makes money through issuance fees. We take a percentage of capital raised.  What sort of Stability Fee are you envisioning for this facility, and initial debt ceiling?  The stability fee would be whatever interest rate the bond is paying. We anticipate Maker will make 10-20% returns. We feel a 5-10M initial debt ceiling is a good size to start.  How is this ‘oracleless’?  Without liquidations, the protocol doesn’t need to know the price of the collateral assets.  Where does the underlying trade, and more importantly who can trade it?  The bonds will not have liquid markets at launch. We plan on adding this as a feature later this year. All trades will need to be performed OTC.

Should we think of these DAO loans together as a CLO with portfolio constraints?  To my understanding, this is exactly how you should think of it.  Is the underlying token collateral marked to market and the debt liquidated if it falls below certain triggers?  We do not liquidate DAOs. Instead, we establish creditworthiness through a credit analysis and rate the issuance. As proposed above, it may make sense for MakerDAO to only offer liquidity to DAOs achieving certain ratings. We also require issuances to be heavily overcollateralized and the issuing DAOs must sign an on-chain promise to repay.

Hi @Jordan, I appreciate the information you have provided in this forum post. Since your application is listed as a MIP6, these applications follow the Collateral Application and template. In addition, you might want to look at MIP67: Methodology and Review Process for Structured Finance Transactions which may apply. Since you are the expert with your collateral, the application is designed to help Maker understand what you are proposing and the market opportunity. Otherwise, the community will spend a lot of time (or not) trying to determine if this is something that makes sense to move forward. I realize the MIP process can be complicated. Part of the service my team provides is to provide consultation on the process. If you have any questions on the process, please let me know. We can also schedule a call if that works better. Thanks!

The collateral applicant has been advised that this application is incomplete based upon the MIP6 collateral application. It is recommended that we hold on the Greenlight Poll (originally scheduled for Jun 6) until the application is updated. It is important for the community to understand what they are voting for or against and this would be challenging based upon a lack of details. Part of our service is to assist collateral applicants with the collateral onboarding process. Let us know how we can help. @Jordan @GovAlpha-Core-Unit

@Jordan Can you please specify how your recent announcement impacts your collateral onboarding application?    Medium – 4 Jul 22   Porter Finance is shutting down its bond issuance platform Today, I am announcing Porter Finance will be shutting down its bond issuance platform.  Reading time: 1 min read       Kind regards, Will
We are no longer applying. Please close this application. Thank you.
